awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms of cell polarity and development of distinct plasma membrane domains during formation of pollen apertures
awd_abstract_narration:
To perform their functions, cells often need to create regions on their surface which will differ from the surrounding areas in their protein and lipid composition. These regions are known as cellular domains. How cells direct molecules to specific positions and produce such domains is poorly understood. Pollen grains provide a beautiful example of a cells' ability to precisely form domains on their surfaces. Pollen surface is typically covered by a protective structure, pollen wall exine. However, in the majority of plants, certain regions on the pollen surface do not receive deposition of exine and instead develop into characteristic gaps, the apertures. To produce apertures, developing pollen consistently marks future aperture sites as different from the rest of the surface and protects them from exine deposition. This project will investigate molecular mechanisms through which pollen creates aperture domains. In the course of this project several young scientists (a postdoc as well as graduate and undergraduate students) will be trained. In addition, pollen biology will be used as a tool to engage and educate the general public through a variety of platforms, including activities at a local science museum, arts class, and a botanical garden.

Formation of distinct cellular domains is critical for cell functions, but the mechanisms involved in creating these domains are still poorly understood. Pollen provides an excellent model for studying these mechanisms. In most plant species, the outer cell wall of pollen grains, called exine, is deposited on the pollen surface non-uniformly, with certain surface areas excluded from exine deposition and developing into characteristic openings, the apertures. Existence of apertures indicates the presence of tightly controlled mechanisms used by developing pollen to specify cellular domains. In this project, the roles of several aperture genes recently discovered in Arabidopsis will be studied to understand the mechanism of aperture formation. Through a variety of genetic, imaging, biochemical, and computational methods, the proposed work will define cell-biological and molecular events involved in this process. It will also explore the questions related to the evolution of pollen aperture diversity and will characterize molecular players that could be responsible for the interspecies similarities and differences in the process of aperture formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To properly perform their functions, cells often need to create regions on their surface that differ in their chemical composition from the surrounding areas. These regions are known as plasma membrane domains. How cells direct molecules to specific positions to produce these domains is poorly understood. In this project, we used pollen grains as our model to study the formation of plasma membrane domains. In pollen, most of the surface is protected by a special cell wall, called exine. However, there are also certain regions on the pollen surface that lack exine. These regions are called pollen apertures, and during pollen development they arise from the distinct plasma membrane domains, known as the aperture domains. In each plant species, aperture number, position, and shape are typically fixed; across species they vary widely.

 In this project, we investigated molecular mechanisms involved in the formation of aperture domains in the plant model species Arabidopsis. We characterized several Arabidopsis proteins that we recently discovered and showed that they play different roles in the formation of aperture domains. We found that several members of the ELMOD family of proteins play important roles in early steps of defining how many aperture domains will form, where they will form, and what shape they will acquire. We demonstrated that two closely related members of the ELMOD protein family, MCR and ELMOD_A, promote the normal formation of three furrow-like apertures in Arabidopsis. Loss of function of these proteins leads to the reduction in aperture number. In contrast, expressing too much of these proteins, creates more than three furrows. Additionally, expression in developing pollen of another member of the ELMOD family, the ELMOD_E protein, which is not normally expressed there, results in a dramatic change in aperture patterns. Instead of three furrows, pollen starts developing multiple circular apertures. We demonstrated that the ELMOD proteins act upstream of the aperture factors INP1 and D6PKL3, ensuring that they get directed to the proper aperture domains. Our findings revealed key players controlling early steps in aperture domain formation, identified protein residues important for their function, and opened new avenues for investigating how diversity of aperture patterns in nature is achieved.

 We also investigated the role of the D6PKL3 protein in aperture formation. The D6PKL3 protein adds phosphate groups to other proteins. We found that during pollen development the D6PKL3 protein gathers at the aperture domains, and that D6PKL3 is required to attract the INP1 protein to the same sites. We also showed that unlike INP1, which does not control the number or positions of apertures, D6PKL3 seems to be able to do so. This difference suggests that D6PKL3 acts earlier in the process of aperture formation than INP1. We found that proper D6PKL3 localization depends on its phosphorylation activity, as well as on the presence of protein region involved in interaction with specific lipids. We identified two lipids that are specifically enriched at the aperture domains.

 We also found that the protein of unknown function INP1, previously shown to be an essential aperture factor in Arabidopsis, maize and rice, is also involved in aperture formation in tomato and California poppy, despite the very different aperture patterns and divergent protein sequences in these species. Furthermore, we showed that INP1 acts together with another protein of unknown function, which we named INP2, that shares some similarity with INP1. We demonstrated that both proteins are essential for aperture formation, with apertures completely failing to develop if ether protein is missing. We also demonstrated that these two proteins physically interact and likely co-evolve. We demonstrated that the INP1 and INP2 proteins from tomato were unable to function in Arabidopsis when each was produced on its own, but they became functional when both tomato proteins were present. This led us to propose that INP1 and INP2 form a species-specific module in which the partners are evolving together. We also studied formation of primexine, the transient cell wall that acts as a precursor of exine formation and is specifically excluded from the aperture domains, and characterized the dynamics of its formation and its composition.

 This project led to publication of 8 research articles and three reviews. It contributed to training of 3 postdoctoral scholars, 6 graduate students, and 13 undergraduate students. We gave multiple hands-on presentations on pollen and plant reproduction to the general public at the local science museum, botanical garden, the Science and Sustainability festival at OSU, and to middle-school girls at the Columbus City School for Girls. We created an educational video and a board game for kids on plant reproduction/genetics that were featured at virtual science celebration festivals. Lectures and hands-on activities were presented at an interdisciplinary Arts and Science undergraduate course at OSU (mostly taken by Arts majors) and at the undergraduate survey course ?Careers in Molecular Genetics?.
